Note.Content: In the meaning of extension toward a goal, εἰς[a] ({D:84.16}) and ἐπί[e] ({D:84.17}) overlap considerably. It is, of course, possible to argue that ἐπί implies being on or at a point, while εἰς defines entering into an area related to some point, but such a distinction would seem to be arbitrary.
In contexts where an accompanying expression designates movement into an area, ἐν[a] and εἰς[d] may be rendered as ‘into,’

There are no doubt certain subtle distinctions in the meanings of the terms in {D:83.9}. For example, πρός[d] may suggest some kind of interaction or response and παρά[b] may focus upon association, but it is difficult, if not impossible, on the basis of existing contexts to define precisely the differences in meaning.
There are probably certain subtle distinctions between the use of διά[c] in contrast with εἰς[h] or ἐν[p] as markers of means, but this cannot be clearly determined from existing contexts.

LEXSense.DefinitionShort: extension toward a special goal{N:001}
extension toward a goal which is inside an area

LEXSubDomains.LEXSubDomain: On, Upon, On the Surface Of

LEXSense.DefinitionShort: a position on the surface of an area
a position defined as being within certain limits{N:002}
a position within an area determined by other objects and distributed among such objects{N:003}
a marker of intent, often with the implication of expected result
a marker of result, with the probable implication of a preceding process
LEXSense.Comments: It is also possible to interpret εἰς in this construction of {S:05300100500014} as purpose (see εἰς[f], {D:89.57}).|It would be possible to interpret εἰς … ἄγω in {S:04500200400040} as being purely an expression of cause since ἄγω[g] (see {D:36.1}) also involves a component of cause, and therefore one may interpret the expression εἰς μετάνοιάν σε ἄγει as ‘it causes you to repent.’ In either case, however, εἰς marks a resulting event or state.

LEXSense.DefinitionShort: a marker of the means by which one event makes another event possible{N:004}
(with the accusative) a marker of content as a means of specifying a particular referent

LEXSubDomains.LEXSubDomain: Up To, As Much As, To the Degree That [Marked Extent of Degree]

LEXSense.DefinitionShort: a degree extending to a particular point as marked by the context
LEXSense.Comments: In {S:04701001500046} περισσείαν itself indicates a superabundant degree of something (see {D:78.31}), while εἰς marks a degree up to such a point. One may say, therefore, that semantically εἰς serves to reinforce the meaning of περισσείαν.

LEXSense.DefinitionShort: a marker of a change of state
a marker of an involved experiencer
LEXSense.Comments: It is possible to translate {S:06000101100030} as ‘trying to find out when the time would be and how it would come’ by interpreting εἰς in {S:06000101100030} as εἰς[i] ({D:90.23}) and ποῖον as {L:ποῖος<SDBG:ποῖος:000001>}[b] ({D:58.30}).

LEXSense.DefinitionShort: (with the accusative) a marker of persons benefited by an event, with the implication of something directed to them
LEXSense.Comments: In both {S:04601600100012} and {S:04700800400028} there is clearly an ellipsis of an event of ‘sending’ such help to and on behalf of God’s people.

LEXSense.DefinitionShort: (with the dative) a marker of objects which serve as symbolic substitutes for supernatural persons or powers presumed to act as guarantors of compliance with oaths

LEXSubDomains.LEXSubDomain: Duration of Time without Reference to Points or Units of Time: Time, Spend Time, Always, Eternal, Old, Immediately, Young

LEXSense.DefinitionShort: a marker of an extent of time
LEXSense.Comments: For another interpretation of {L:εἰς τέλος<SDBG:τέλος:000003>} in {S:05200201600042} (as an idiom), see {D:78.47}.

LEXSubDomains.LEXSubDomain: Indefinite Units of Time: Age, Lifetime, Interval, Period

LEXSense.DefinitionShort: a marker of a unit of time

LEXSubDomains.LEXSubDomain: Duration of Time with Reference to Some Point of Time: Until, Delay, Still, From

LEXSense.DefinitionShort: the continuous extent of time up to a point
LEXSense.Comments: The phrase εἰ μὴ {L:ὅταν<SDBG:ὅταν:000000>} is often translated as ‘until’ (for example, μηδενὶ ἅ εἶδον διηγήσωνται, εἰ μὴ {L:ὅταν<SDBG:ὅταν:000000>} ὁ υἱὸς τοῦ ἀνθρώπου ἐκ νεκρῶν ἀναστῇ ‘not to tell anybody what they have seen until the Son of Man has risen from death’ {S:04100900900028}), but this phrase may be analyzed as meaning ‘if it is not when,’ an expression which is semantically equivalent to ‘until.’|For an interpretation of {L:εἰς τέλος<SDBG:τέλος:000003>} in {S:04301300100062} as an idiom, see {D:78.47}.

LEXSense.DefinitionShort: (an idiom, literally: to come into knowledge) to acquire information about something, with emphasis upon the process involved
LEXSense.Comments: It is also possible to treat the phrase εἰς ἐπίγνωσιν ἔρχομαι as meaning ‘to come to know’ in the sense of ‘to come to understand’ (see {D:32.17}).

LEXSense.DefinitionShort: (an idiom, literally: to come into knowledge) to come to understand the meaning of something, with special emphasis upon the process
LEXSense.Comments: One may also interpret εἰς ἐπίγνωσιν ἔρχομαι as meaning ‘to come to have knowledge of, to come to know’ (see {D:27.4}).

LEXSense.DefinitionShort: (an idiom, literally: into that which is not measured) a point on a scale going beyond what is expected
LEXSense.Comments: In a number of languages one can perhaps best render this statement in {S:04701001300008} as ‘we will not boast too much’ or ‘we will boast only so much.’

LEXSubDomains.LEXSubDomain: Duration of Time without Reference to Points or Units of Time: Time, Spend Time, Always, Eternal, Old, Immediately, Young

LEXSense.DefinitionShort: unlimited duration of time, with particular focus upon the future
LEXSense.Comments: See also {S:04200103300018}; {S:06100301800044}; {S:06500102500052}; {S:05800100800028}. The more elaborate expressions employing {L:αἰών<SDBG:αἰών:000000>} are somewhat more emphatic in meaning and are to be found especially in the solemn style of doxologies.|For another interpretation of εἰς τὸ παντελές in {S:05800702500008}, see {D:78.47}.

LEXSubDomains.LEXSubDomain: Not Able To Be Known, Secret

LEXSense.DefinitionShort: (an idiom, literally: into the ear) pertaining to what is known only by those who hear a particular message in private
LEXSense.Comments: A phrase such as ‘whatever you hear in secret’ may be rendered as ‘whatever you hear when no one else is listening.’

LEXSense.DefinitionShort: (an idiom, literally: to come to the worse) to become increasingly more sick

LEXDomains.LEXDomain: Moral and Ethical Qualities and Related Behavior

LEXSense.DefinitionShort: (an idiom, literally: to be in the gall of bitterness) to be particularly envious or resentful of someone
